DC Public Schools added a new photo — with Ron Brown College Preparatory High School and Norfolk State University.
June 25 at 1:51 PM ·

Maurquice Brown-Thomas has always been a sports fan. In his downtime, he started learning about statistics, which led him to begin managing the basketball team at Ron Brown College Preparatory High School. When he attends Norfolk State University in the fall, Maurquice will blend his experience on the basketball team and his interest in science to pursue a major in exercise science and kinesiology. When he thinks about the staff who supported him during his four years at Ron Brown, it’s difficult for Maurquice to pick just one person who has had the biggest impact on him. His coaches, social worker, and athletic director each played critical roles in his life. But Dr. Cohens and Ms. Jackson, who were with Maurquice since day one at Ron Brown, ensured that he was supported both in the classroom and on the field. “They crafted paths that I can follow, so I can be successful.” Maurquice’s advice to incoming high school freshmen: “Take every opportunity given to you, and if something doesn’t go your way, keep working and always stay humble.” #DCPSGoesToCollege

To help students transition into SY20-21, we will hold a Summer Bridge program for students entering grades 3, 6, and 9. If health conditions allow, Summer Bridge will take place in-person Monday through Thursday from August 10-13 and 17-20. Advance registration will be required.

The first day of school for students is Monday, August 31, 2020, and the last day of school for students is Thursday, June 24, 2021. Explore the full SY20-21 calendar online at dcps.dc.gov/page/dcps-calendars.

Our goal is to recruit a diverse group of parents who can represent all students and families’ voices across the District.

Complete the application online: bit.ly/dcpschancellorparentboard

You can also request a paper application by texting (202)480-3166 or by emailing ceo.info@k12.dc.gov.

Applications are due by June 30 at 11:59 p.m.

Through the trip, he toured the campus and met students – an experience that he says made him realize that the school would be a good fit. “They are giving me an opportunity,” says Diante, and he plans on taking full advantage of that opportunity. During his time at Ballou STAY, Diante says his favorite class has been digital animation – a topic he had not previously explored. Through the class, he learned how to create an animated cartoon based on a self-portrait. He says that he has appreciated Ballou STAY’s mastery-based program. “I can work at my own pace,” says Diante. Thinking about what advice he would give younger students, Diante says he wants them to stay focused on their goals. “Don’t let [anybody] tell you that you can’t do what you want to do.” #DCPSGoesToCollege
